items.title: How to find location of exception in template
items.body:
Hi all,

I'm rendering a template that has many variables inserted, quite a few where I'm using jinja's round() to control the formatting.

However if one of my variables I'm filtering is not defined, then jinja/docx-template will through an exception: 'Undefined doesn't define __round__ method'.

_Unfortunately, in trying to track down which variable is missing, the exception doesn't provide any more information about _which_ variable is missing, or the location in the template file._

So my questions:
- is it possible, with this type of exception, to get the variable that is undefined and/or the location in the template?
- is it possible to avoid this exception by changing the default type from Undefined or (preferrably) adding a round() method to Undefined?
- is it possible to tell jinja to not through exceptions on these errors?

items.title: how to return the rendered result  as a stream ?
items.body:
normally , we have these codes :
 tpl = DocxTemplate(tpl_file)
tpl.render(xxxxxx)
tpl.save(file_path)

but in the case of a web service,we need to return the rendered result as a stream for the caller, for example:
 return StreamingResponse( stream )

Is there any way  that  we can use something like:
tpl.to_stream()
?

items.title: Losing hyperlink in subdoc
items.body:
#124 

Hey there - I was able to use an existing docx object as a subdocument, and almost everything worked perfectly (formatting, text styles, etc.). The one thing that didn't work was a hyperlink - the text was formatted like a link, but there was no address associated with it. Should it be possible to take in a docx object with a link as a subdoc, and have that link be populated in an output file using a docx template?

Let me know if that's confusing...

Thanks!

items.title: replace_pic with file object
items.body:
Let me first say how happy I am with docxtpl!
However,  I came across an issue.

In my script I generate a new image and use is to replace an image in a document. Initially I saved the replacement picture locally, and then loaded it to do the replacement. It would be more elegant to directly substitute the replacement file instead.
I used this in another application where I apply InlineImage instead.

With replace_pic  I can not make it work. Most likely I am doing something wrong. There is no error, but the replacement picture can not be displayed in the document.

I made a minimal example: a script test_file_object.py and a template my_template.docx. The variable use_file_object can be set to either True or False to either use the file object or the image stored locally.

You can easily see the image is replaced as the line in the template is blue and replaced by red upon substitution.


[test_file_object.txt](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/4943674/test_file_object.txt)
[my_template.docx](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/4943675/my_template.docx)

Hi. This a continuation from https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/issues/280

[REDACTED.zip](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/4793293/REDACTED.zip)


Inside the zip file you have two files. The `.py` and the `.docx`

`list_images` contains the exact structure I get on my output (sql query) like the documentation.
`list_images_manual` is the same structure but written manually.

The difference between both is that `list_images_manual` doesn't have double quotes on InlineImage.

I want to do the same on `list_images` but my `list_images` cames from a SQL Select Query, so it's not always the same. I already tried to remove it but I can not do it.

cheers,

items.title: Add Images in a Nested Loop
items.body:
I want to add images to my docx document.

Using the normal way as in the docs, InlineImage works just fine.
`'catimage': InlineImage(doc, '/media/46c9f2d6-bcc4-4b32.PNG')`

Now, I'm trying to add multiple, so I followed the structure in
https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/master/tests/inline_image.py

And my structure looks like this:
```
'images': [
    {
        'id': 799, 
        'image': "InlineImage(doc, '/media/d781dffb-f0da-4025.png')"
    },
    {
       'id': 790, 
       'image': "InlineImage(doc, '/media/64cbfe54-e0c3.png')"
    }
]
```

Then in my template I have a validation. Something like:
```
{% for image in images %}  {% if image.id == XXXX.id %}
{{ image.image }} {% endif %} {% endfor %}
```

but it does not work! it renders the text. so instead of getting the image, I get the 'image' content string (InlineImage(doc, /media........).

Is is because of having double quotes instead of singles quotes in the structure? I've been trying to replaced them with single quotes to take that out of the equation.

items.title: Text deleted by {%- and -%} merging feature
items.body:
Hi there! I believe I'm seeing a bug in the new `{%-` `-%}` merging feature introduced in version 0.9.0 (references: [commit](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/commit/97be69b950830188435b22d07b0c218cafd026c7), [documentation](https://docxtpl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#split-and-merge-text)) where some document text is being deleted. It's very strange. It seems to happen sometimes when there is a non-whitespace character immediately before or immediately after the `{%-` or `-%}` tag. But it doesn't always happen. See the attached document, where there are two identical sequences of text, one where the problem happens and another where it doesn't. It seems like it must depend on some unseen structure of the document. Or possibly there _is_ some subtle difference between the two sequences that I'm overlooking.

In any case, I wouldn't expect the merging feature to ever delete non-whitespace. Is this the expected behavior?

### Screenshot of the template docx
![Screen Shot 2020-04-28 at 10 42 16 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/225813/80503367-c0465080-893f-11ea-9cbf-93ed1af6e969.png)

### Screenshot of the rendered docx
![Screen Shot 2020-04-28 at 10 42 34 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/225813/80503380-c3d9d780-893f-11ea-9305-4c6ffabae238.png)

### The template docx
[merge_paragraph_should_only_delete_whitespace.docx](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/4546662/merge_paragraph_should_only_delete_whitespace.docx)

### The rendered docx
[rendered_output_from_v0.9.2.docx](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/4546663/rendered_output_from_v0.9.2.docx)

items.title: ValueError: target_part property on _Relationship is undefined
items.body:
I used docxtpl v0.6.3 in order to generate 3 docx based on 3 templates.
One template contains headers and footers

Since the update to v0.8.0 (where you use python-docx (0.8.10)), generating that third template gives the following error:
```
File "C:\Users\xxx\Desktop\xxx.py", line 476, in <module>
    doc.render(context)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python37\lib\site-packages\docxtpl\__init__.py", line 294, in render
    self.map_headers_footers_xml(relKey, xml)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python37\lib\site-packages\docxtpl\__init__.py", line 266, in map_headers_footers_xml
    new_part.load_rel(rel.reltype, rel.target_part, rel.rId, rel.is_external)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python37\lib\site-packages\docx\opc\rel.py", line 161, in target_part
    raise ValueError("target_part property on _Relationship is undef"
ValueError: target_part property on _Relationship is undefined when target mode is External
```

Can this be solved here, or is it a python-docx issue ?

items.title: Add Jinja2 whitespace controll
items.body:
When having long paragraph where some words/sentences are shown only on condition, the syntax gets very messy. 
Instead of:
```
My house is located {% if living_in_town  %} in urban area {% elseif %} in countryside {% endif %} and I love it. 
```
something like this would help a lot:
```
My house is located
{%- if living_in_town  -%}
  in urban area 
{%- elseif -%}
  in countryside
{%- endif -%}
and I love it.

items.title: replace_zipname does not work for embedding xlsx files into docx documents
items.body:
Related with [comment](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/issues/221#issuecomment-611553187) in issue #221.

I tried to embed a xlsx file following the simple (thanks for making them simple) in the most recent (v 0.7) [documentation](https://docxtpl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/).

Attached is the most simple reproducible example I came up.

```
from docxtpl import DocxTemplate

nameDocx = "test_docxtpl.docx"
nameAnex = "new_embedded.xlsx"
nameInsertedFile = "word/embeddings/Microsoft_Excel_Worksheet1.xlsx"
###########################

doc = DocxTemplate(nameDocx)

doc.replace_zipname(nameInsertedFile, nameAnex)

doc.save(nameDocx)
```
[replace_zipname_xlsx.zip](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/4473620/replace_zipname_xlsx.zip)

items.title: How to insert multiple paragraphs
items.body:
We have a list of paragraph objects that are ready with custom styles. Is there a way we can insert them using one or many (jinja2) tags with the help of this library?

I see that there is the subdoc template variable (https://docxtpl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#sub-documents) that helps us insert subdocuments.

```
    tpl=DocxTemplate('templates/subdoc_tpl.docx')
    sd = tpl.new_subdoc()
```

Is there a way to do this for docx Document objects? Or a way to convert them into a subdoc object?

items.title: Diagnosing failer render()?   ...how to get more info
items.body:
Hi there,

I'm docx template v0.6.3 with python-docx 0.8.7 and had some great success with it.  I'm using it to generate moderately complex reports, with images, and most of the time working well.

However I do have one big problem - when something fails during render() how do you figure out what/where the problem is?

For instance, I'm currently having render() fail and the exception I'm getting back is simply:
`'Imgtype'`

Is there a way to get more informative information when render fails as to where and why?

This is a huge problem for me, as trying to diagnose what a problem is on a moderately complex template with only that info is pretty hard!

thanks,
Richard

items.title: How to generate index (bibliography)?
items.body:
Hi, I'm trying to create a index in my docs. The library correctly creates the entries but it does not assign the correct page numbers and hyperlinks in the index.
The following piece creates the entries in the index:
```console
for item in items %}
{{ item.id}} – {{ item.name }}
{% endfor %}
```
The index creates entries up to level 4.
After manually updating the index with one click, it's good, but I'd like it to be automatically good.
Is there a right way to do this? Any suggestions?
Thanks

items.title: Conditional cell background formatting problem
items.body:
Hi there,

Quick thanks first for an awesome package!

I'm trying to selectively set the background color of cells in a tab based on the cell value, but can't seem to get it working.

In my table I have a cell defined as
`{{ m.thick_error | round(1) }}`
This works fine - I get the value of my 'thick_error' variable printed with a single decimal place.


Now what I'd like to do is specify the background color only if the value of 'thick_error' is ' too big'. ...this is an error value variable, so a value too high is a problem and I'd like to highlight those cells.

If I use a jinja {% if... %} with a plain text  between the endif, it works, in the sense I only get the string included based on the result of the if:
`{% if m.thick_error|abs() >  10 %} BIG {% endif %} {{ m.thick_error | round(1) }}`
In the above, I only get the string 'BIG' in front of the variable value if it's absolute value is greater than 10.

However, if I try the above, but instead use cell background color setting in place of the plain text 'BIG' above, it doesn't work: _all the cells_ have the background color set, regardless of the 'if':
`{% if m.thick_error|abs() >  10 %} {% cellbg ‘555555’ %} {% endif %} {{ m.thick_error | round(1) }}`

I don't know jinja well, but is there a way to have the {% cellbg %} only get used based on the surrounding if?

thanks!

items.title: Image will always be lost when insert multiple subdoc in which more than one subdoc contain picture
items.body:
Step:
1  Prepare a template which has more than 2 subdoc template
2  Prepare 2 subdoc, each contain a image. When unzip de subdoc docx, image is named image1.png in both docx.
3  Render the template with subdoc.
Expect:
All subdocs are inserted with right image.
Result:
Only 1 image1.png is kept in final output docx, both inserted docx use this image1.png as its image to display.

I do more for that:
I do not insert the docs with subdoc, but just extract all sub elements except image, then fill the  extracted elements to output docx. After that, I add_picture to output docx, then the picture will be numbered rightly. So I think it may be not perfect when process image with same name in different subdoc.

items.title: Question: Can not replace image with replace_pic function
items.body:
Firstly, thanks for your excellent work of this project.

## Environment
- OS: Windows 10 1909 (18363.535)
- Python: 3.7.5
    - docxtpl: 0.6.3
    - python-docx: 0.8.7
    - jinja2: 2.10.3
    - six: 1.13.0
    - lxml: 4.4.2
- Office: Office 365 1911 (12228.20364)

## What
Can not replace image with replace_pic function

## How
I insert a image into document's `body` and I know the image will be renamed by `word processor`. So I reformed the `template` suffix name from `.docx` to `.zip` and observed the image in path `\word\media` with name `image1.png`.  When I run
```python
from docxtpl import DocxTemplate
doc = DocxTemplate('template.docx')
doc.replace_pic('image1.png', 'some_img.png')
doc.save('generated.docx')
```
a `ValueError` occurred: `Picture "image1.png" not found in the docx template`

## Why (Analysis)
When I read the source code, I find
https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/4fe1cc507d23cca68a8d78208dcb803a312578ec/docxtpl/__init__.py#L530
and the `docx.oxml.ns.nsmap['pic']` goes [that](https://github.com/python-openxml/python-docx/blob/da75fcf01f7f322e846e2ac3e1936aedd766acc8/docx/oxml/ns.py#L19)
```python
'pic': ('http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/drawingml/2006/picture')
```
When analyzing `document.xml.rels` in `\word\_rels` path, I find the `namespace` of `png` format is `http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/officeDocument/2006/relationships/image`, which is not represented in `docx.oxml.ns.nsmap`.

Maybe this is the problem?

items.title: Generation of corrupted docx when there are tables in subdoc
items.body:
Hi @elapouya ,
First of all this is a great library and has really helped us do our project with ease.

We're currently facing a problem, where we have a table in a sub-template, which we render in our main template as a subdoc. However, the generated docx is corrupted, and we are unable to open without using Word's recovery.

We compared the xml of both the corrupt and recovered docx files, and there seems to be an issue in the w:p tags in the table, where the corrupted xml doesn't have paraId and textId, while the recovered doc has them.

Corrupted:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31321664/70391463-9bd2f180-19fb-11ea-8e0a-50b27bfa53e6.png)

Recovered:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31321664/70391468-a9887700-19fb-11ea-9fe4-b0bf5a1a35dd.png)

Here are the [main template](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Dvpsn09K7Kt_EeT-ahZ2no3V8G4z1dah/view?usp=sharing) and the [sub-template](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JaABkGi9tMQZmDOfBG_fY_yRuch4cITN/view?usp=sharing) (containing the table).

And the corrupted and recovered xml files attached too.
[corrupt1.txt](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/3936470/corrupt1.txt)
[recovered1.txt](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/3936471/recovered1.txt)

items.title: Using the "p" Tag in a "set" Command
items.body:
Hello,

Love this library!

I have a question/minor request:

Sometimes I use the {% set %} command in a template to dynamically set a variable in-line. However, this always results in an extra carriage return. I've tried using the "p" prefix to strip out the return, but this is not recognized. (eg. `{%p set [var] = [value] %}` )

I've always found some other way to handle these particular scenarios in the backend without relying on {% set %} in the document, but I was thinking it would be a great addition to be able to use the "p" prefix in set commands!

Hi,
I have a problem to generate a table, as follows:
Here is the template in my use case.

items.title: Insert SubDoc Without Line Break
items.body:
Hello,

I'm running into an issue where I'm unable to insert a sub-document without having an extra carriage return after the insert. If I want to place text directly below the insert, there is always an extra line break between the two.

eg.

{{ inserted subdoc }}< lb >
< lb >
< content that comes after the subdoc >

I'm wondering if there is a clever way to strip the extra line that comes after the insert, similar to the `{%p if %}` and `{%p for %}` solutions

Also, if I have subdoc at the end of a document, it adds the extra carriage return and can sometimes cause an extra blank page at the end of the assembled document because the extra line causes the content to spill into another page. Or if the subdoc is in the header/footer of the document, it creates an unnecessary space at the bottom of the header/footer

items.title: Hyperlinks from Sub-documents are broken
items.body:
Hello,

I am trying to build a docx report, and I paste some content from other docx files as sub-document.

The problem is that hyperlinks from sub-documents are broken after rendering the template.
[Subdoc with links](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/3660864/subdoc.docx)
[Template for adding subdocs](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/3660866/one_subdoc_only.docx)
Code example:
```
from docxtpl import DocxTemplate


tpl = DocxTemplate('one_subdoc_only.docx')
sd = tpl.new_subdoc('subdoc.docx')
context = {
    'subdoc': sd,
}

tpl.render(context)
tpl.save('one_subdoc_only.docx')
```

items.title: Combine multiple docx files created from same template
items.body:
Hello,

I am wondering if anyone has any guidance on how to combine/merge multiple docx files (all created from the same template). I was trying to model the below code that I came across while searching this topic:
doc = DocxTemplate("template.docx")

pages = []
for idx, data in enumerate(dataset):
	page_doc = DocxTemplate("page_template.docx")

    page_doc.render(context=data)

    sd = doc.new_subdoc()
    sd.subdocx = page_doc.docx

    pages.append(sd)

context = {"pages": pages}
doc.render(context)

doc.save("final.docx")

However, the generated docx is overlaying the contents, instead of creating separate pages, with page breaks. Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks so much!

items.title: Unable to Include both Ampersand (&) and Newline Characters (\n) in Templates (can only do one or the other)
items.body:
Hello,

I've been struggling with this issue for a few months now with no luck. Every time I think I've found a solution, there's an edge case that throws a wrench in it. I'd greatly appreciate any help!

The problem is that I can't find a way to accommodate both "&" and newline characters at the same time in my templates.

If I set `autoescape=True`, "&" characters merge fine in inserted variables as well as in the content of the document. But any newline characters in variables are replaced with empty spaces. I've tried replacing newlines with the XML equivalent (<w: br / >) in my `finalize` function. I've also tried to insert paragraph tags, etc. However, those are all XML solutions, which are escaped by the `autoescape` option. I tried replacing "\n" with literal newlines, but I think that essentially replaces "\n" with "\n"

If I set `autoescape=False`, I can replace "&" and newlines with their XML equivalents using my `finalize` function, and that works great! However, "&" characters in the static content of the templates are then replaced with "& amp;" (instead of being properly escaped). I can prevent ampersands in the content from being replaced in this way, but then they're stripped out completely instead of appearing normally. This is definitely the closest solution to what I'm after, the only problem is that "&" are not being properly inserted in the static content of the templates.

I've scoured the issues on this repo but none of the relevant issues seem to address my specific problem.

I'm using the library in a large-scale application with many templates and a big range of possible inputs. As such, I don't think any use of the RichText solution would be scalable (as far as I understand - I don't have much experience using RichText tools).

Please if anyone can point me in the right direction I would be incredibly grateful!

items.title: replace_embedded does not work with Excel files
items.body:
I'm trying to use docxtpl to replace embedded dummy Excel files using the replace_embedded method. Naturally since I'm writing this, it doesn't work the same way as it does with .docx files.

After some digging, it appears that Word changes the CRC of Excel files when they are embedded, which means the method does not find the files within the document. I verified this by manually creating a file with the right CRC - the replacement then works as expected.

Do you know some way around this? Maybe there is some way to calculate what the new CRC will be? If that's not possible, some way to manually type the CRC into the method would be helpful.

Thanks for making this wonderful module by the way.

items.title: Not preserving spaces in run text with Jinja code after patching XML
items.body:
On docx editor (either Microsoft Word or LibreOffice) you have in the middle of the paragraph something like this `a {%r if TEST %}b{%r endif %} c` which most probably will be translated in the document.xml in something like this:

```xml
<w:p>
  <w:r>
    <w:t>a {%r if TEST %}b{%r endif %} c</w:t>
  </w:r>
</w:p>
```
When this gets parsed by **docxtpl** patch_xml you get something like this ([code](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/master/docxtpl/__init__.py#L102)):
```xml
<w:p>
  <w:r>
    <w:t>a </w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t>{%r if TEST %}</w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t>b</w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t>{%r endif %}</w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t> c</w:t>
  </w:r>
</w:p>
```
And then docx editor will render this `abc` instead of the correct version `a b c`

Technically this is the form of XML required:
```xml
<w:p>
  <w:r>
    <w:t xml:space="preserve">a </w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t>{%r if TEST %}</w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t xml:space="preserve">b</w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t>{%r endif %}</w:t>
  </w:r>
  <w:r>
    <w:t xml:space="preserve"> c</w:t>
  </w:r>
</w:p>
```
Notice the introduction of `xml:space="preserve"` (see: [openxml doc](http://officeopenxml.com/WPtext.php)) which will solve the problem on rendering time.

items.title: replace_media fails if DocxTemplate is reading and writing to file-like object
items.body:
The following code as self.post_processing will try to rename the in-memory file object
```python
import io
file_obj = io.BytesIO(some_content)
file_obj.seek(0)

t = DocxTemplate(file_obj)
t.replace_media('dummy.png', 'other.png')
new_obj = io.BytesIO()
t.render(context)
t.save(new_obj)
```
This throws the error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./header_footer_image_file_obj.py", line 33, in <module>
    tpl.save(file_obj)
  File "C:\Users\EricDufresne\Desktop\python-docx-template\docxtpl\__init__.py", line 543, in save
    self.post_processing(filename)
  File "C:\Users\EricDufresne\Desktop\python-docx-template\docxtpl\__init__.py", line 456, in post_processing
    os.rename(docx_filename,backup_filename)
TypeError: rename: src should be string, bytes or os.PathLike, not _io.BytesIO
```
Simply in the case that a file-like object is being post processed, the temp file must also be in memory using a new BytesIO() object.

items.title: Add file like object support for replace_media
items.body:
I am trying to replace a header and footer image but because of file-system constraints all of my objects are file like objects (io.BytesIO objects) and not actually on disk. 

```python
import io
from docxtpl import DocxTemplate

file_obj = io.BytesIO(input_stream)
t = DocxTemplate(file_obj)
other_file_obj = io.BytesIO(other_input_stream)
t.replace_media('image.png', other_file_obj)
```

This obviously throws:
```
TypeError: coercing to Unicode: need string or buffer, _io.BytesIO found
```

Simply the ability to pass a byte or string io object just like how it's done in the Template __init__ method would be great.

items.title: Unable to use hyperlinks properly.
items.body:
Hello,

I saw the documentation on how to create hyperlinks in RichText and I tried following it, but the generated documents are corrupted and the hyperlink does not show up.

My use case:
I have a DocumentTemplate.docx file which, at some point, lists the terms of using a particular service:

```
{%p for term in standard_terms %}
{{r term }}
{%p endfor %}
```

I also have a python script that manipulates the data that does in the document.
Most terms are simple text, but there are some that refer online documents:

`The customer acknowledges the associated terms and conditions from: **external_doc**. The customer is advised to print and keep these documents....`

I use the following code to manipulate the input data:
```python
rt = RichText(term)
# I use documents to check where I have to add the external doc ref
if "{documents}" in term:
    # remove the documents text
    rt.xml = rt.xml.replace("{documents}", "")
    dt = DocxTemplate(TEMPLATE_FILE_PATH)
   # documents is a list of external docs
    for doc in documents:
        rt.add(doc , url_id=dt.build_url_id(DOCUMENTS_URL+doc ))

standard_terms.append(rt)
```

At a later stage, I generate the report like this:
```python
    doc = DocxTemplate(TEMPLATE_FILE_PATH)
    print("Generating the report {}".format(report_name))
    doc.render(input_data, j2_env)
    doc.save(report_name)
```

Am I doing it wrong?
I'm using the latest version of docxtpl(0.5.17), python 3.6 and Word 2016.

Thanks.

items.title: vertical merge problem
ZeroDivisionError since v0.5.12
items.body:
I am encountering a problem with a template which worked fined when using v0.5.11. Below i have tried to make the simplest demonstrator possible

[template_zero_division.docx](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/files/3080231/template_zero_division.docx)

```python
doc = DocxTemplate("template_zero_division.docx")
context = {'results': [{'entry': 1}, {'entry':2}, {'entry': 3}]}
doc.render(context)
```

When i am on v0.5.12 or higher (only tried v0.5.17), this template fails with a ZeroDivisionError, from [this line](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/master/docxtpl/__init__.py#L358).

This is added in v0.5.12 in [this commit](https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/commit/8ffc7b80e815b5dcd0b49f595b6d04757909bfc8).

It would be great if you could look into this.

items.title: How to use special characters in template variables in docxtpl?
items.body:
Hi guys,

I have to use special character in jinja fields, such as '@' in filename like 'show_logging@10.0.0.253.txt'

I managed to make a script to loop the docx to find all fields, combine them with path and load this file into Listing object.

But when I tried to use the method provided by Martijn Pieters in this post [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29344964/how-to-use-special-characters-in-template-variables-in-jinja2](url) , I got this error
```
  Original exception was:  
  Traceback (most recent call last):  
    File "./aj_docxsearch_test.py", line 53, in <module>  
      docxtpl_1.render(context1=context)  
  TypeError: render() got an unexpected keyword argument 'context1'  
```

Here is my code, and there is only one line in test_special_char_in_field_tpl.docx
“{{ context1['show_logging@10.0.0.253.txt'] }}”  (without quotes)

```
#!/usr/bin/env python3.6

## https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29344964/how-to-use-special-characters-in-template-variables-in-jinja2 @Martijn Pieters

import re
from docx import Document
from docxtpl import DocxTemplate, RichText, Listing

template_1 = "test_special_char_in_field_tpl.docx"
filepath='logfiles/'


regex1 = re.compile(r"{{.? (?:\w*\[')?([\w@.]+)(?:'])? }}")

textJinjaFields = []
docxtpl_1 = Document(template_1)

for p in docxtpl_1.paragraphs:
    if regex1.findall(p.text):
        textJinjaFields += (regex1.findall(p.text))

for t in docxtpl_1.tables:
    for t_row in t.rows:
        for r_cell in t_row.cells:
            for c_paragraph in r_cell.paragraphs:
                if regex_1.findall(c_paragraph.text):
                    textJinjaFields += (regex_1.findall(c_paragraph.text))

context = {}


for index, item in enumerate(textJinjaFields, start=0):   # Python indexes start at zero
    with open(filepath+item, 'r') as tempfile:
        text=tempfile.read()
    context[item] = Listing(text)

docxtpl_1 = DocxTemplate(template_1)
docxtpl_1.render(context1=context)
docxtpl_1.save("test_special_char_in_field_tpl_new.docx")

```

# Distribute `removed_width` across all columns that has
                # left after extras removal.
                extra_space = removed_width / len(columns_left)

```
I have used a slight variation of the https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/master/tests/dynamic_table.py example. 

Along with a slightly modified template https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/master/tests/templates/dynamic_table_tpl.docx

If I simply copy everything as it is in the original examples into my current template it works.
The challenge I have and the change I made is to the table layout.

I need help. The only way I can get it to work is by keeping the first cell i.e. your example "Color of think"

The desired outcome is for `{%tc col in col_labels %}` to produce my columns, and to iterate through `tbl_contents` to produce the correct number of rows and `item.cols` to populate the cell values.

The dynamic count example has a slightly more complex table structure, and I guess my issue is trying to normalise the structure.

items.title: DocxTemplate method fix_tables: AttributeError: 'bool' object has no attribute 'get'
items.body:
The problem is the following line at file lib/python2.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py +330

```
grid_span = tc_pr is not None and tc_pr.find(ns + 'gridSpan') 
```

grid_span is False after the execution of the previous line.

I think we need to change the next line:

```
if grid_span is not None:
```

to 

```
if grid_span:
```

I could create a pull request and will try to make an unit test

```
 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/lcubo/workspace/faraday/server/utils/executive_reports.py", line 95, in create_report
    hosts, services)
  File "/home/lcubo/workspace/faraday/reports/executive/generic_report.py", line 330, in create_document
    tpl.render(context, jinja_env)
  File "/home/lcubo/.pyenv/versions/faraday4/lib/python2.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py", line 264, in render
    tree = self.fix_tables(xml_src)
  File "/home/lcubo/.pyenv/versions/faraday4/lib/python2.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py", line 338, in fix_tables
    cells_len = functools.reduce(get_cell_len, cells, 0)
  File "/home/lcubo/.pyenv/versions/faraday4/lib/python2.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py", line 331, in get_cell_len
    return total + int(grid_span.get(ns + 'val'))
AttributeError: 'bool' object has no attribute 'get'
```

items.title: Python Docx 0.8.8
items.body:
Hi,

Since python-docx 0.8.8 (Add support for headers and footers https://github.com/python-openxml/python-docx/blob/master/HISTORY.rst#088-2019-01-07), render with python-docx-template does not work anymore.

Dump (python-docx==0.8.8, docxtpl==0.5.16):
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/handlers/exception.py", line 41, in inner              
    response = get_response(request)
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/handlers/base.py", line 187, in _get_response          
    response = self.process_exception_by_middleware(e, request)
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/handlers/base.py", line 185, in _get_response          
    response = wrapped_callback(request, *callback_args, **callback_kwargs)                                                          
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/views/generic/base.py", line 68, in view                    
    return self.dispatch(request, *args, **kwargs)
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/views/generic/base.py", line 88, in dispatch                
    return handler(request, *args, **kwargs)
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/views/generic/detail.py", line 117, in get                  
    return self.render_to_response(context)
  File "views.py", line 138, in render_to_response                               
    engines[self.engine_name].env)
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py", line 299, in render                                
    for relKey, xml in headers:
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py", line 247, in build_headers_footers_xml             
    for relKey, xml in self.get_headers_footers_xml(uri):
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py", line 238, in get_headers_footers_xml               
    yield relKey, self.xml_to_string(parse_xml(val._target._blob))
  File "lib/python2.7/site-packages/docx/opc/oxml.py", line 37, in parse_xml                                 
    return etree.fromstring(text, oxml_parser)
  File "src/lxml/etree.pyx", line 3230, in lxml.etree.fromstring (src/lxml/etree.c:81070)                                            
  File "src/lxml/parser.pxi", line 1870, in lxml.etree._parseMemoryDocument (src/lxml/etree.c:121231)                                
ValueError: can only parse strings
```

Apparently, there has been a lot of change in the way header and footer are managed and now, val._target._blob value is None in the get_headers_footers_xml

```
    def get_headers_footers_xml(self, uri):
        for relKey, val in self.docx._part._rels.items():
            if val.reltype == uri:
                yield relKey, self.xml_to_string(parse_xml(val._target._blob))
```

items.title: ValueError: can only parse strings
items.body:
I installed docxtpl on a clean machine today. I ran some code that used to work but couldn't generate any document.

The exact same exception is raised when running the basic usage code from the documentation.

```python
from docxtpl import DocxTemplate

doc = DocxTemplate("my_word_template.docx")
context = { 'company_name' : "World company" }
doc.render(context)
doc.save("generated_doc.docx")
```

Using Python 3.7.1

Traceback:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-70cd50864075> in <module>
----> 1 doc.render(context)
      2 doc.save("generated_doc_.docx")

/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py in render(self, context, jinja_env, autoescape)
    297         headers = self.build_headers_footers_xml(context, self.HEADER_URI,
    298                                                  jinja_env)
--> 299         for relKey, xml in headers:
    300             self.map_headers_footers_xml(relKey, xml)
    301 

/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py in build_headers_footers_xml(self, context, uri, jinja_env)
    245 
    246     def build_headers_footers_xml(self,context, uri,jinja_env=None):
--> 247         for relKey, xml in self.get_headers_footers_xml(uri):
    248             encoding = self.get_headers_footers_encoding(xml)
    249             xml = self.patch_xml(xml)

/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/docxtpl/__init__.py in get_headers_footers_xml(self, uri)
    236         for relKey, val in self.docx._part._rels.items():
    237             if val.reltype == uri:
--> 238                 yield relKey, self.xml_to_string(parse_xml(val._target._blob))
    239 
    240     def get_headers_footers_encoding(self,xml):

/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/docx/opc/oxml.py in parse_xml(text)
     35     ``etree.fromstring()`` replacement that uses oxml parser
     36     """
---> 37     return etree.fromstring(text, oxml_parser)
     38 
     39 

src/lxml/etree.pyx in lxml.etree.fromstring()

src/lxml/parser.pxi in lxml.etree._parseMemoryDocument()

ValueError: can only parse strings
```

I tried to investigate, maybe it's related to this URI being unreachable, but I'm not sure at all   https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/2fad92046e580b6e9a212647f274d5efaae82648/docxtpl/__init__.py#L41

items.title: unicode string can't be autoescaped by render
items.body:
the code is
```python
if isinstance(v, str):
     # Unescape at first to avoid secondary escaping
     d[k] = escape(unescape(v))
```

when the v is the unicode, for example：u"\u4f60&\u6211", the escape can not handle it. is it added unicode type to if judgment.
```python
if isinstance(v, (str, unicode)):
     # Unescape at first to avoid secondary escaping
     d[k] = escape(unescape(v))
```

items.title: Image cannot be displayed
items.body:
Hi there, 
first of all I really like your project, it's very useful and easy to use. 
Now to the issue:
I generated a template to insert multiple tables and multiple pictures in the same word template .docx and the python code and function I wrote in order to render these has worked very well.
Since yesterday, however the figures are not displayed in the generated word document anymore. I get the error message: 'This image cannot currently be displayed' and the red cross in the upper left corner.
Was there an update that might have affected this?

items.title: Template syntax error unexpected char '
items.body:
When i try to use a custom filter with a string argument like this 
{{ myvalue|myfilter('myargument') }} i get an error 

jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError:unexpected char '''.

Please help with an example of custom filter which shows how to pass a string argument. Integer  arguments are passed without issues. 

I have later discovered while going through other reported issues, that this is due to the fact that the straight quotes ' are automatically converted to curly quotes ‘ which are not identified by jinja as valid character. While pasting the quote from another editor like atom works but this does not look like a good solution. One has to modify the autoreplace default setting of word which automatically changes straight quotes to curly quotes.  

Has any body tried the patch_xml() fix as reported in this thread 
[https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/issues/85](url)

Pasting the code at line 47 does not help me.

items.title: docxtpl not working with python2

E       nonlocal hash_values
E                          ^

```

I'm not sure if the project stopped to support python 2.

The commit that broke backwards compatibility is this one:
https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/commit/40bf39cde7fb9e00c70fbab15ddef106873e920b#diff-44a6068875277a2a5854743f0ed4e7deR182

items.title: Listing seems to break on ints and probably other non-string-type objects

I was thinking that casting non-strings to strings would fix this. what do you think?

Ref:
https://github.com/elapouya/python-docx-template/blob/b987864c3f4d0d2572a16a28388fd912f06bc505/docxtpl/__init__.py#L487

items.title: Assignments in template
items.body: Are assignments in the template possible? I.e. the way they are handled in Jinja2: http://jinja.pocoo.org/docs/2.10/templates/#assignments

items.title: Using 'render' multiple times
items.body:
@elapouya,
Why does rendering multiple variables not work? For eg:

```
from docxtpl import DocxTemplate

doc = DocxTemplate("template.docx")
doc_date = { 'date':"14th Sept. '18" }
period_covered = { 'period':"1st January 2018 – 31st December 2018" }

doc.render(doc_date)
doc.render(period_covered)
```
It updates only the first variable.
